subject: It's not a black or white matter.  Or is it? ( was Re: Testing Private Methods)
msgSnippet: ... ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Thank you Bob for coming up with a clever and catchy answer to the seemingly perennial [how do/should] I test private methods
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
> I don't feel bad about making private methods package scope in order
> to test them. Testing trumps encapsulation.
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Thank you Bob for coming up with a clever and catchy answer to the seemingly perennial
"[how do/should] I test private methods" question.

I really like the "Testing trumps encapsulation" phrasing because it implies relative and not
absolute value judgements. It meets the spirit of Testivus (http://www.artima.com/
weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=194506).

Sure, ideally the design and implementation is such that you don't have to break
encapsulation, but often circumstances are less than ideal.

The assert on privates vs. don't assert on privates issue is something that we have been
debating amongst ourselves at Agitar for years. The current version of JUnit Factory
creates asserts for private fields. I still cringe a little bit when I see them. But if we
remove them, users complain.

A possible solution, suggested by someone else at work, is to partition the generated tests
into black-box tests and white-box tests src directories.

The black-box tests can only assert (and use) public stuff - they can't violate
encapsulation.

The white-box tests can peek and poke wherever they want.

I haven't given this idea enought thought to reach a conclusion, but I found it intriguing
enough to share it and solicit feedback.

Alberto
